page.title: 01Eversley Village
page.content: { Eversley}is mentioned in the original Domesday Book. The name means Boar's Meadow. It is scattered over a wide, rural area of forest and farmland, but the three main areas are The Street, The Centre and Lower Common. The village has grown from two smaller villages. The school links the area geographically while the church is a little distance away on a site of pre-Christian worship. The population is about 1,500.The forest is owned by The Forestry Commission. It is mainly evergreen and surrounds a quarry where gravel is extracted. The farmland is mixed, growing things like cereals and potatoes. There are a few sheep and many cows and poultry. {Charles Kingsley}was the rector of Eversley from 1844-1875. He founded the local school, which is named after him, in 1853.
